elements.facilitator: The most effective instructional designers possess interdisciplinary knowledge, effective communication skills, excellent problem-solving ability, and a commitment to lifelong learning.

rubric.content:
To become an instructional designer, you should consider building your skills in these five key areas

@@[0]Instructional designers understand how people learn and use this knowledge to create solutions for specific learning goals. This includes knowledge of:

  • learning theory and psychology
  • instructional strategies
  • curriculum planning
  • learning objectives
  • assessment
@@ @@[1]The more instructional designers understand about business and management, the better they are able to meet their clients’ goals. Instructional designers can benefit from having skills in the following areas:

  • project management
  • evaluating business outcomes
  • meetings and presentations
  • data collection and analysis
  • marketing
@@ @@[2]Instructional designers need to understand the strengths and limitations of various technologies, so they can select appropriate delivery media for learners. Skills in the following areas may be useful:

  • eLearning development software
  • office software
  • programming
  • Learning Management Systems (LMS)
  • quality assurance and testing
@@ @@[3]Because ID projects require a lot of collaboration, Instructional Designers need to have excellent interpersonal and communication skills, including:

  • writing and editing
  • interviewing and note-taking
  • persuasion and change
  • coaching and mentoring
  • conflict resolution
@@ @@[4]Creativity is what separates good and great instructional design. While creativity may be applied to all facets of the ID process, instructional designers may also have the following creative skills:

  • graphic design
  • audio/video
  • user experience design
  • animation
  • games and simulations
@@
